JProcessing

Class Processing.PGraphics

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Window

              • JProcessing.Processing
                • JProcessing.Processing.PGraphics
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants
    Enclosing class:
    Processing

    public static class Processing.PGraphics
extends Processing
    PGraphics is a Stand-alone Offscreen Graphics Rendering Context Inherits all Functionality of JProcessing.

    A JProcessing alike GUI Rendering Context, directly Extending Class Processing.
    Unlike JProcessing.Processing, PGraphics is designed to Draw and Store rendered Result in an Offscreen frameBuffer instead of Outputting them directly on Screen. The Rendered Image can either be Drawn to the GUI window using Image(PGraphics,x,y), Image(PGraphics,x,y,w,h), or Obtained as PImage using .get().

    PGraphics in JProcessing works Primarily Identical as of in Processing IDE. However, as the Instructions on the Processing Website Forbidding the Construction of PGraphics Class using Syntax new PGraphics(w,h), such Method is totally Allowed in JProcessing and will have the same result of Calling Method createGraphics(w,h).

    Note that PGraphics is set not Active and will Not update its frame According to the Frame Rate. setup(), draw(), redraw(), and loop() have been marked as Deprecated and final to Prevent Calling or Overriding such Methods which would otherwise result in Unexpected Behaviors.

    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    PGraphics in Processing IDE, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • PGraphics

        public PGraphics(int w,
                 int h)
        Create a new PGraphics graphics context with resolution specified by w and h.

        This is done by creating a new invisible borderless JProcessing window at the size bounded by w and h. The JProcessing GUI window is set deactivated using noLoop(). The rendered result will be stored in frame buffer and not be displayed on screen.

        This constructor works exactly the same as method createGraphics(w,h).

        Parameters:
        w - width of the graphics context
        h - height of the graphics context

    • Method Detail

      • setup

        @Deprecated
protected final void setup()
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from class: Processing
        Processing void setup() function, invoked after JProcessing being initialized.

        setup() will be invoked only once at 100ms after the initialization of new JProcessing, before the draw() is invoked. Data loading, variable initialization, and environmental property definition should be done in setup().

        Under normal circumstances, setup() should not be manually invoked again after its initial execution.

        Overrides:
        setup in class Processing
        See Also:
        <void setup()> in Processing IDE

      • draw

        @Deprecated
protected final void draw()
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from class: Processing
        Processing void draw() function, invoked before the update of every frame.

        draw() will be invoked repeatedly at the frequency up to the GUI's frame rate specified by frameRate(rate). if the task in draw() takes too long to finish, the frame rate will be lowered to the rate of completion of draw() in each second.

        Only Functions that need to run at every frame should be put inside draw(), such as graphics rendering, image displaying, mouse or key input detecting etc. Time consuming tasks such as image loading should not be done in draw(), otherwise will lower the frame rate dramatically. Instead, they should done in setup() or asynchronously in another thread.

        If a new frame is needed to be updated manually, use redraw() to render a single frame. It is very uncommon to find situations where draw() needs to be executed without the actual update of contents on the screen. In that case, draw() can be invoked manually but it will not be thread safe. In that case, it is recommended to add synchronized modifier when overriding draw().

        Overrides:
        draw in class Processing
        See Also:
        <void draw()> in Processing IDE, Processing.redraw()

      • redraw

        @Deprecated
public final void redraw()
        Deprecated. 
        Description copied from class: Processing
        Processing redraw() function, execute the code within draw() one time and then manually update a frame.

        This should only be used when the automatic frame update is disabled by noloop(), otherwise it will have no effect. Upon calling, the draw() method will be immediately invoked, then a new frame will be rendered after the completion of any previous ongoing render task.

        Do not call this method within draw(), otherwise the program will run into infinite loops.

        Overrides:
        redraw in class Processing
        See Also:
        <redraw()> in Processing IDE

public final void loop()
